criticReviews.criticPost: It's a summer love-fest with Manhattan.
[The episode was] anything but a fluff piece for the holiday.
Tthe ribald, underwear-free Samantha Jones we all know and love puts her stamp on Season 2 of The Carrie Diaries.
It's not only going to be the season, but the summer of Sam, and that fact alone has me Jones-in' for more.
This season of The Carrie Diaries starts out as sweet as we expected it to and I can't wait to find out what other kinds of troubles Carrie and Samantha get into this season.

While it's not surprising that The Carrie Diaries is unlikely to appeal to fans of the HBO franchise, it's still disappointing that much of what made that series work has given way to cliche and oversimplification.
If this show wants to take us on a tour through all the Mr. Littles, it deserves a shot.
This is a different series, one whose good start has to do with its capacity to be affecting.
There's not enough Visine in the world to soothe the eyeball-rolling that greets the arrival of CW's Sex and the City prequel series, The Carrie Diaries.
Mostly boilerplate teen soap that lacks the (umm) zest of Sex and the City -- a good thing, in case you're wondering.
It's not relationship material, but you wouldn't feel guilty about spending a night with it.

In the case of The Carrie Diaries, the CW series that takes Sex and the City fashionista and sexual anthropologist Carrie Bradshaw all the way back to 1984 Connecticut, and high school, the fit's a little off.
It will be interesting to see as the show goes forward how it will deal with a few '80s issues.
The rest of the show goes on to prize sweetness over superficiality.
It'll hit the mark for younger viewers and there certainly are some moms who may enjoy tailgating.
The Carrie Diaries, a prequel to Sex and the City, which begins tonight on the CW, has an infectious if semi-idiotic positive attitude.
Writer Amy B. Harris has crafted a clever, credible script, carefully adding a few veiled life lessons within the witty dialogue.

Robb is instantly appealing as a 16-year-old Carrie Bradshaw in The Carrie Diaries, a fun and frothy Sex and the City prequel that dares to imagine what its beloved leading lady was like before she started dating Mr. Big and having cosmos with the girls.
The Carrie Diaries is the first time in almost three years that I've had a warm thought for Carrie Bradshaw because the new series succeeds on its own nostalgic terms.
The CW's attempt to capture the magic of Sex and the City in a prequel, set in 1984, could have gone very wrong. But The Carrie Diaries is surprisingly right.
Since the creators... are as uncertain about the tone of the show as they are about its audience, viewers are likely to be more puzzled than entertained.

The CW's The Carrie Diaries is like a real-life video version of that old story The Monkey's Paw, in which a mother's wish for the return of her dead son results in a shambling, mutilated corpse knocking at her door.
It's a step above the typical CW soap, and worth penciling in an appointment in your own TV diary.
Passable yet too often cloying little trinket.
There is no attraction in living through the most awkward years of your life all over again.
Hearing Liam Neeson as Qui-Gon is sensational...

It seems like a rollicking adventure and conspiracy yarn set in the narrative universe of a famed and lucrative media franchise, but every now and then, you scratch away at the surface and find something very purposeful.
Overall I loved, loved, loved this season of the Clone Wars it's fantastic...

It could be that I was savouring every last moment I had left with the series, but Season Six may be the strongest so far, taking in 5 very different and tightly held together story arcs over its all too short 13 episode run.
The camerawork when Anakin, Fives, and Tup walk across the outside of the space station is elegant and appropriately dizzying. It, like the rest of the episode, was convincing and excellent.
As ever, the jaw-dropping sophistication of the animation plays an enormous role in making the episodes come alive.
The Clone Wars began its sixth and final season with an exciting installment that included some very appreciated touches.

It works to rectify the mistakes of the prequels by filling in all the gaps and adding many, many layers of nuance to the major characters. It manages to have fun while also telling serious and sometimes even tragic stories.
A complex and thrilling start to the final season with a few minor flaws that drag it down slightly.
Star Wars is always better when it leans toward its darker side, and that's certainly true of the batch of The Clone Wars episodes, dubbed The Lost Missions.
The final arc was the season's best, as it focused on Yoda's adventurous journey that gives some very important insight into the past and future of the whole "Star Wars" saga.
The Clone Wars team have done a wonderful job of expanding the Star Wars universe over the last five years with this show and the animation has come on in leaps and bounds.
There's good stuff here, it's just that it feels like they were holding the best stuff back for Season 6...
The Clone Wars may end eventually, but its stories and characters will stay with Star Wars lovers forever.
This episode underscored what good villains Maul and Savage are, in that it's cool to see them be menacing and also thrilling to see them get beat, since it's firmly established how nasty they are.

It's light fare-after all, it's a Saturday morning cartoon-but it effortlessly takes you into the world of Star Wars, a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away. As a result it's highly enjoyable: fascinating and immersive and fun.
As mouthwatering a visual feast as Season 4 is, there's a sense that we're being increasingly denied the payoff from the fan-servicing plot arcs set up in the previous season...

There are, as always with this show, some excellent set pieces, made all the more spectacular in their underwater environment. But the visuals cannot really overcome the stodginess of the story and the rather bland characters.
Still, there was plenty to be impressed by throughout.
As I wrote last year, as bad as the animated Clone Wars movie was, I've really come to like the series-on its own action-adventure terms-as it has developed and found its voice.

It's lovingly made and I've no doubt it would be my favourite show ever if I were just that couple of decades younger. It's exciting, cool, funny and - if the second half of this season is anything to go by - it's getting even better.

I also have to commend the animation in this episode, which included some stunning shots of a rain-soaked Kamino that looked pretty much photo-realistic. The animators are doing some truly commendable work on this show at this point.
Also, you know that the villains aren't going to get their comeuppance since they're still active later in the storyline, so you're left with a show about some people doing stuff.

It's also great to see more ongoing storylines developed - while the specific story in the Jedi Archives is wrapped up by the end of the half hour, there are major threads set into place for the next episode and perhaps beyond.

The animation has improved [and] is more emotionally resonant. The CG is actually really good for a television show... and they introduced quite a bit of really interesting expanded universe storylines that you can actually get really invested in.
The Clone Wars will certainly polarise Star Wars fans, but if you can lose the baggage it offers fairly solid entertainment.
Featuring familiar, and not so familiar characters from the Star Wars series, we're presented with an occasionally meaty series for a 'children's show,' let alone an animated one.
There's more attention to character development; Jabba the Hutt's flamboyant uncle isn't anywhere to be found.
If you judge this series by the standards of the original trilogy--i.e., if you expect it to be good--then yes, it's as disappointing as the summer movie it follows.
The heroes are as brave as ever, in their mythological ways, and the villains are as ruthless as they come.
Watching Yoda take apart a squad of tanks with his little lightsaber is just as much fun as it's supposed to be.

However, where the prequels failed, the Clone Wars and Rebels succeed - not just by filling in surface-level plot threads... but by chronicling subtle nuances that inform how an entire Galaxy was manipulated by fear.
The new series aspires to the level of a virtual-reality game. That's both the source of its great visual charm and the key to its emptiness, which is too dull to get worked up about.

Perhaps more significantly, Clone Wars - drawing from all the quadrants of the Star Wars universe - brought the fun back to Lucas' creation, which, in the movies, at times came to feel like an obligation.
Well, viewed on its own merits, this is a well done, entertaining series.

The stylized animation takes some getting used to, especially when dealing with familiar characters, but the storytelling just improved over the series' run, until by the end, it was arguably more emotionally sophisticated than the films that inspired it.
This will be a show long remembered.
Complexity is fine, but when the plot is Byzantine and the characters lack all depth, the result is either irritation or boredom.
The Saturday morning serial pacing and style - not to mention the half-hour format - gets things moving quickly.
Believe it or not, Star Wars: The Clone Wars is pretty cool. Not the theatrical film, which underwhelmed critics and died at the box office. But rather the computer-animated TV series.
And now, with the final episodes of Star Wars Rebels in the books, those fans have been rewarded with a thorough-and thoroughly exciting-concluding chapter of the rebels' story.

This isn't to suggest that tonight's episode, 'Rebel Assault', is a bad installment or that it takes the season off track - quite the opposite, in fact - but having it serve as midseason finale makes for an arbitrary point in the action to hit pause.
Star Wars Rebels easily could have lasted another year or two before taking its final bow, but at least it ends on its own terms.
'Heroes of Mandalore Parts 1 and 2' provides an action-packed introduction to the season that also speaks to over-arching themes.
As long as those endings are satisfying, as long as they honor all of the wonderful characters, Rebels' four-year journey will have been a successful one.
Star Wars Rebels just gets back to brass tacks, pushing much of the show's arcs to the side to focus on one: Sabine, the Mandalorians, and the vague but powerful weapon she helped create.
It's certainly not all fun and games anymore, but it hadn't gone full darkness yet. It hasn't lost the spirit of hope that it's always had, which made it so special in the first place.
It was at times gripping, other times solemnly reflective, but was mostly a solid end for what has been a rather good season of Star Wars Rebels.
Now that's a Star Wars war story.
One of the many great things about Star Wars Rebels is that it exists in this interstitial space where there is a lot of story to mine and lots of colorful, charismatic characters who populate it.
Really, it's just a lot of crazy action, and it's just really well-done, and not quite as burdened down with questionable objectives, like Rogue One's endgame.
The beloved villain's arrival in the season premiere certainly lived up to the hype...

If you're not watching this then you're missing out - it's far more than just filler while you wait for the films. Rebels is quietly but confidently crafting its own unique take on a galaxy far, far away, and doing a great job in the process.
An abundance of fun, with high-spirited action (including dazzling space battles and impressive lightsaber duels), dry wit, and dramatic contributions to the Star Wars mythology.

Once again hewing closely to the spirit and template of the original, the show continues to revel in the latitude afforded by animation to dole out bountiful helpings of action, garnished with considerable wit and a welcome sense of fun.

I kind of like this new take on Ezra. He started as a pseudo-Chosen-One, smart alec kid, but now he comes across as a more sure-footed Steven Universe, a positive, go-for-broke apprentice that makes for a great little foil.
The battle-hardened Commander Wolffe and senile Gregor make this troupe one of the more entertaining ensembles in the Star Wars Universe.
Whatever the characters are up to, however cute or sentimental the business, it is smartly designed and cinematically staged, and not hard to enjoy.
[Rebels] is a shipshape, neato-burrito side project that finds the right balance between hype and hyperspace.
Rebels, in its unassuming way, looks like it will be a smart and sensitive piece of entertainment.
The Force is indeed strong with this one.

All of the nostalgic aural elements that might stir a dormant fan's heart are there, but the prequels had plenty of that. What those films lacked, and Rebels immediately shows off, is characters you can actually buy into.
It had a couple of stumbles here and there, but overall, Star Wars Rebels' first season was a rousing success.
It's a surprisingly tight, focused story clearly backed with a budget way beyond other CGI action cartoons.
The animated series is so well written and the characters so intriguing that adults may enjoy this new addition to the saga as much as kids will.
Unlike the original movie, the series won't be fun for the whole family. But the two-dimensional dialogue, characters and plots should keep sci-fi-minded kids entertained.
Fun animated series focuses on female Star Wars heroes.
This is by far one of the best thing that the prequels saga ever gave us.
As a mini-feature, Clone Wars isn't compelling all the way through; the battles get repetitive and a little excessive.
Messages contrived to make ideological points have a way of exacting a toll from drama-usually a flattening predictability-and this series is no exception.
It does fine work in shadows and close quarters, the influence of the co-executive producer Thomas Schlamme (The West Wing), a veteran TV director with a knack for creating theatrical intimacy.
This is the kind of evolution that all-time great series take, and it wouldn't surprise me one bit to see Manhattan get to the status that it deserves.
Manhattan isn't quite yet the great show I know it's capable of being as season two begins, but it's a show that moves with the confidence of a series that knows it can be great.
Frank's the one with the vision and grit Charlie Isaacs is looking for, and he's the one whose absence pulls all the main characters together.
The series by Sam Shaw and Thomas Schlamme captures an American past with detail like no series since Mad Men and has an enviable cast.
It captures the enormous creative possibilities that come from putting a few hundred great brains together on one army base in the middle of the New Mexico desert, but also the problems that arise.

Hickey and Williams are individually fascinating actors who, together, heighten the dramatic stakes of even the most incidental domestic scene, investing their work with a Eugene O'Neill-heaviness that soars -- I think that's something of a miracle.
Manhattan is an overwrought, overripe piece of pulp fiction stuffed with overboiled intrigue.

It still features a superb and growing ensemble cast, a textured commitment to period detail, the smooth execution of some of TV's best directors and the looming potential of atomic detonation to give it all some dramatic juice.
Things heat up (literally) in the second hour with Justin Kirk in a guest role. The increasingly engrossing first four episodes move through D-Day.
Television has no shortage of male characters with large egos and conflicted hearts, but Hickey makes Winter's flaws and his stoic endurance equally intriguing.
It's as well acted and intriguingly plotted as any of TV's period dramas.
Paranoia is kept at a fever pitch. One of the elements that makes Manhattan work so well as long-form narrative is that the milieu dictates a palimpsest of networks of secrecy.
Manhattan is a well-conceived period drama that does a good job conveying the atmosphere of tension and secrecy that surrounded The Manhattan Project during the later years of WWII.
In this oversaturated summer of quality drama, "Manhattan" faces tough odds. But it's hard not to root for an underdog.

The show feels a little bit too nice, a little too PG -- even an against-the-wall make-out session and a moment of woman-on-woman flirtation feel oddly chaste, even anthropological - but the show still fascinates.

Manhattan is awfully overwrought, stocked with personalities as volatile as the radioactive isotopes they're trying to tame. Its melodramatic tone makes it resemble Lifetime's Army Wives more than it does A Beautiful Mind.
Manhattan is the result of an unlikely attempt to cross-pollinate Lost with Mad Men, only the audience knows the answer to almost every mystery on the show is "the atomic bomb."
The cast is incredibly talented and the story tightly written.
The premiere does a fine job of creating a sense of time and place and introducing a complicated subject.
Carrying the weight of the world can be heavy lifting. Manhattan so far shows every sign of being able to shoulder the load.
With intelligent protagonists and a story that still holds resonance today, Manhattan is absolutely worthy of our attention.
The show... is a solid, involving big-canvas drama that plausibly re-creates a time and place and fills it with some original characters.
Manhattan... is as exciting as the history that inspired it
As a thriller, Manhattan mostly works.
It's easily one of the most beautiful hours of television to come along this year.
The performances are good, the writing is good, and the premise is good, but the complication of our own history is involving and fantastic.
Even with its flaws, Manhattan might find its formula. The second episode is already brisker and more subtly intriguing in places than the first - exciting, even.
Manhattan has so far-it's early-delivered no sermons about the alleged immorality of the bomb, which doesn't mean there won't be any.
Manhattan succeeds as the emotional, personal side of things starts taking hold.

The show has a rich period feel, with the proper clothes, appliances and a slightly bleached-out look that nicely captures the heat and desolation of the New Mexico desert where the real-life Manhattan Project was located.
Manhattan is the must-watch drama of the summer. You can watch it on the Cubs channel.
If anything, the season 5 premiere proved that time jumps can offer more than just intrigue as to what transpired since the characters were last seen.
For the first time, Clarke has the space to contemplate what it means for her fight to be over.
It's a bold choice, but one that's bolstered by the cleansing nature of last season's finale.

After the hot mess of S3 and S4 The 100 gets a much needed hard reset and largely succeeds. 3 out of the first 4 episodes returns the show to glory and features an emmy level performance from Eliza Taylor. Its once again can't miss TV.
Season four finally premiered and brought with it some much-needed answers: ALIE was telling the truth.
The 100 deals with loss, grief, and trauma in just about every episode, and it's smart and nuanced in its portrayal of how humans confront all three.
The premiere picked up mere moments after the jaw-dropping events of The 100 Season 3 Finale. This made for an action packed (and super plot-heavy) installment.

For longtime fans of The 100, the new season finds viewers rewarded with a deeper look at the characters, including what drives them and what it takes to have them make unexpected and sometimes questionable decisions.
Octavia has gone through an amazing metamorphosis from an unsure girl who led a very solitary, even lonely, life into a rock-solid, kick-ass woman who can handle any situation laid in her path.

The return to Bellamy and Clarke as leaders, and a paring down of the overall number of story arcs will likely be a good thing, since Season 3 suffered from mischaracterization and separating too many of the major players.
No matter how season 4 unfolds, it's clear The 100 has chosen the hardest path yet again -- by pitting its characters against their most formidable problem yet, one with no solution in sight.
Plenty of characters still don't know the truth, but there's strong potential this season to explore just how varied people's reactions will be to being told the end is nigh.
The themes present here are similar to past seasons, but the characters have grown.

I can't emphasize enough how much I love this show, and how much I feel like it so perfectly combines the moral quandaries of society with the complexities of human emotion on screen, through a balanced cast of adult and teen characters no less.

Despite the show always hold the belief that they keep their viewers on the edge of their seats, this is the first time where the threats against our favorite characters feel real and tangible, with no one seemingly safe from danger.

Even though I wanted to save myself aggravation, I was curious. Season 4 starts ok, but it has a LOT to make up for after last season's train wreck. The show could return to greatness if it just killed Bellamy, Jaha and Jasper.

Should be used as a case study on how to destroy a once great show by turning all of your characters into unlikable, xenophobic murderers in service of season long plot threads that are beyond stupid.
As season three opens, we find that the show is as ambitious and cruel as ever, with "Wanheda Part 1" throwing us right back into its complex, ever-growing world.

"Wanheda: Part One" sets up some exciting conflicts, both between the Sky People and the Grounders as well as among the main characters, that are sure to provide more compelling sci-fi/action drama throughout The 100 season 3.
The continued expansion of the Grounder world offers a lot of intrigue and I'm, as always, excited to see what happens next.
The 100 is once again ready to tackle bigger themes related to war, loyalty, morality, and identity.
The show continues to grapple with the psychological consequences of the wrenching end of season two through believable character development.
"Wanheda: Part One" was a smooth transition back into the world of The 100, an hour that had a lot to do but managed it all with relative ease.
With its third season, the show keeps getting bigger, bleaker, and better.

The 100 absolutely explodes in season three; the characters fascinate, the moral murkiness of the plot thickens, and the scope of the world expands to mythical proportions in wondrous, gripping, and appropriately novel ways.
After a conflict on as huge a scale as the one this season, it'll be interesting to see what the show will do to top it.
The second season of The 100, visually, morally and thematically, quietly builds on the strengths of Season 1.
This episode let us know the status of every character we care about and love, as well as establishing the different groups the show is going to be tackling
I'm looking forward to learning more about the Grounders and the various factions.
I dig this show. I think it's really fun and creative and, frankly, it bugs me a lot to see some people clearly pre-judge it, sight unseen.
The 100 has once again established a mysterious and inventive tone, one that answers just enough questions while asking a whole lot more.
The 100 is setting the stage for an exciting new season, and I can't wait to see what the writers have in store for Clarke and her less than loyal followers.

This CW sci-fi drama earns points strictly for forward momentum, launching into its second season featuring a fast-evolving narrative, with the space-faring human population returning to Earth and facing a new set of problems.
The 100 entertained.

The series raises potentially interesting questions, and though the beginning of the episode may have been dragging because of informational purposes, towards the end I really did feel intrigued to find out what is hiding in the woods.
There's a lot to like here, with things getting impressively dark and edgy in the episodes to come.
The 100 has a lot of interesting things to play with in terms of its narrative and world-building, but it chooses to gloss over them.
There's a reason why CW's new sci-fi drama is called The 100 - because it rips off about as many sources, from Lord of the Flies to The Hunger Games, for this messy young adult sci-fi stew.

The CW's promotional campaign for The 100 seems most interested in its pretty people and its two-faced deer, but in between all of that, Rothenberg and company are sneaking in a surprisingly sophisticated look at a world filled with want.

It's more like another CW teen drama in different clothes with hot girls, bad boys, cliched talk and staged fights. That it's based on a series of books gives it more heft than most such CW dramas, but it's almost drowning in backstory.
The visuals are strong, the characters are enjoyable enough, and there's a lot of mystery to engage with.

There are, to be sure, some suspenseful moments and effective sequences. (Homemade knives occasionally give it the air of a 1950s juvenile delinquent film.) There are luminous butterflies to marvel at and strange beasts to contend with.
After one episode, I'm sold. The tension felt authentic both in space on and on ground. There are two worlds unlike our own to explore and to be revealed.
The CW's The 100 is the latest in a long line of Lost imitators, but it's also one of the better efforts.
At the very least, The 100 boasts a curious premise and I hope it finds an audience going forward.
A high-concept guilty pleasure that comes as a bit of a creative relief after a dreary season of derivative spin-offs, reboots and retreads (reaching a nadir in Star-Crossed and The Tomorrow People).
I'm still struggling to find a single character whose fate I'm even vaguely invested in, but my outright antipathy towards some of the characters ha[s] begun to fade.

It has a sensibility and swagger that places the new series in good company. The 100 is better than it has to be, a little more exciting and surprising and intense. It's that margin that excites me about the show.
It makes for lively drama, with sharply defined conflicts and characters who aren't always all good or all evil.
You know, for a post-apocalyptic dystopian scenario, The 100 is actually pretty hopeful.
The 100 won't make any must-see lists, but with minor tweaks, it could at least have been harmless fun for an underserved demographic.
Yes, it's a CW series, but one that poses enough lifeboat-ethics issues to keep a freshman philosophy class busy for months.
The question is which is more dangerous, the guy in the bone helmet with the big club or the writer providing the leaden dialogue.

Now I understand there was a lot of red tape to deal with and the show was actually cancelled at a point before the season 5 official renewal, but it feels like we really went off course from whatever was the originally intended storyline.
I'm happy to see it back, and clearing up some of the confusion.
Since only three weeks is meant to have passed since we last saw everyone, you'd think there wouldn't be any major developments, but life really can change with the snap of a finger.

Once you look past the trappings of the hokey premise (and the often generic legal proceedings) there is a central emotional core of reinvention and emotional growth to the show that easily sucks you in.
Too bad the high concept premise - Heaven Can Wait meets Legally Blonde - also sticks them with a reactionary gender politics.
Despite the serious subject (not to mention some preachy, PSA-style dialogue), the breezy humor remains intact.
There's lots of strained girl talk. But there's also a really bold center, a sense of what it's like to find yourself, very gradually, in a whole other life.
As it has wandered away from its core body-switch concept and allowed its characters to become more than caricatures, Drop Dead Diva has emerged as one of summer's unexpected pleasures.
Newcomer Brooke Elliott is both charming and surprisingly credible as Jane-inhabited-by-Deb. She's a find.
A minor delight for viewers who seek engaging escapist fare.

The Lifetime press materials quote from a half-dozen women's groups, which heap praise on the network for creating a plus-size role model. But in truth, this show is filled with mixed messages about the links between appearance and self-esteem.

The cleverest thing about Drop Dead Diva is its title - and if, over its 13-week run, the writing rises to that level of droll wit, this could turn out to be the TV equivalent of a good old-fashioned summer beach read.
While it sounds pedantic, downright corny, and done to death, Drop Dead Diva is actually fun, funny and sometimes and in some ways even touching.
Drop Dead Diva is a lot of fun to watch, with the added bonus of introducing TV audiences to Brooke Elliott, a stage actress with fabulous comic timing and enormous dramatic flexibility.
In the most implausible of comic mixups Ms. Elliott is convincing, and even affecting, at every turn.
Drop Dead Diva relies too much on stereotypical characterizations of women - the dumb blonde, the homely intellectual, the vampy temptress, etc. - to be wholly fresh and original.

Berman's script, despite a slight lean toward preachy empowerment, is surprisingly engaging. And Elliott is a find, a full-blown instant star and delight who makes you wonder where she has been hiding herself.
There's much to be said for a program featuring a smart, plus-sized heroine in today's rail-thin TV world, but Diva undernourishes its premise amid a sea of legal-procedural banalities.
